description:
The applicant requests approval of a
Development Review Permit (16ENT-0096), Variance (16ENT-0097), and Vesting
Tentative Tract Map (16ENT-0131 & 19ENT-0192) for a three- and four-story, 14-unit
condominium project with associated landscaping and subterranean parking located
at 423-429 Ocean Avenue. The proposed project includes retention of portions of
the extant apartment buildings and the courtyard area associated with the City
Landmark-designated Colonial Revival style garden apartment complex. Variances
are requested to allow for encroachments into required yard setbacks, to exceed
allowable parcel coverage, and to modify off-street parking requirements. The
property is located within the R4 (High Density Residential) District. Please see environmental reports page for the associated EIR for the project.

title: Living the California Dream: African American Leisure Sites
description:
Alison Rose Jefferson, M.H.C, Ph.D. is a historian and heritage conservation consultant. Her research interests explore the intersection of American history and the African American experience in southern California, particularly during the Jim Crow era, historical memory, public history, spatial justice, and cultural tourism, with an aim to engage broad audiences through applied history projects in the struggle for social justice. Her book titled, Living the California Dream, African American Leisure Sites during the Jim Crow Era (University of Nebraska Press) which arrives in January 2019, rethinks the significance of the struggle for leisure and public space for all within the long freedom rights struggle. Book sale and signing to follow.

Dr. Jefferson is the project historian for the City?s Belmar History + Art project, a public art project that commemorates the historic Belmar neighborhood at what is now the Santa Monica Civic Center campus. For more information, visit http://santamonica.gov/arts/belmar.

title: Central Avenue Jazz
description:
Two leading experts: Steve Isoardi and Steve Loza, discuss Los Angeles' historic Central Avenue jazz scene.

From the 1920s to 1950s, Central Avenue was LA's base for African-American music, like 52nd St. in New York, with numerous clubs hosting touring stars and local players. Historian Steve Isoardi will speak on Central Avenue and jazz in South LA in general. He is the author of 'The Dark Tree: Jazz and the Community Arts in Los Angeles' edited the oral history 'Central Avenue Sounds,' and collaborated with LA music legends Horace Tapscott and Buddy Colette on their memoirs.

Bandleader Gerald Wilson came up playing trumpet on Central Ave. and went on to compose and arrange for numerous artists, as well as leading his own big band and teaching at UCLA. Working steadily until his 2014 passing at age 96, Wilson affected many styles and generations. For example, a cover of his song 'Viva Tirado' by the band El Chicano has become a iconic hip-hop beat, and Kamasi Washngton built his reputation as the star soloist in Wilson's last band. UCLA ethnomusicology professor Steve Loza, who worked with Wilson and recently published a book on him, will speak on his career and legacy.

Both presentations will include audio and video recordings, and a question and answer period will conclude the program.
